comments.commentBody: I think it's possible to raise legitimate criticisms about the demonization of DDT without pulling out what is pretty clearly a myth about a global ban leading to millions of deaths in poor countries. I often disagree with FAIR.org assessments, but the portion of this piece on DDT mythology on the use of DDT in many developing countries is, as far as I can tell, correct.

«TB, malaria, AIDS — cause more than 5 million deaths each year»

And one of them, malaria, could be easily beaten back if DDT were allowed back.

Good article, Mr. Revkin, emphasizing the contrast between rich and poor societies. But I think the millions who die in poor countries each year only because the environmentalists in rich countries banned DDT is an even more stark example of the gulf that separates rich from poor.

What about all the simple sugars, and hydrated glucosed dissolved in liquid that makes kids instantly hyper? Gthem so much fuel and expect them to sit and quietly concentrate?

How about the who knows what, the unlabelled cocktail that is in the cow's milk (anti-biotic bi-products, growth hormones) that the cow was fed throughout its super-industrial diet?

It's not just that kids have these behavioral abnormalities from their alien diet (though doctors on the industry's payroll refuse to weigh-in this evidence).

Kids are growing to abnormal sizes, like dog breeds that shouldn't exist, they are growing in ways that are physiologically incompatible with normal behavior.

That effect is above and beyond the so-called improved diet. Some mothers may worship these supersized children, but we don't need such physiques for modern day functions. No one is rooting for a crusade requiring Hercules and Xena.

Please, take care of your infants and children. Feed them organic milk, and complex carbs.

To those who are defending artificial additives: If there is ANY possibility of harm from an unnecessary artificial food additive, a petroleum produce added to food for purely cosmetic reasons, why is there any debate?
Risk: Maybe Benefit:None. Its a pretty simple decision.

Anyone else notice that sugary foods are the ones that tend to have food coloring? If your kids are hyperactive you should probably be avoiding brightly colored sugar cereals in the first place. Whole grains, fruits, veggies, meat and dairy are all free of dyes, and these items are typically found around the perimeter of the grocery store.

Count me and my parents as people espousing the anecdotal evidence that the Feingold diet works to control hyperactivity. Many battles were fought between us over food, but in the end, it all worked out. I didn't have to be on Ritalin throughout my childhood. And now as an adult I am already very familiar with reading food labels, something that has just become fashionable in the past few years. Junk food doesn't make it into my house very often, not because I'm the Nutrition Police but because I just never had a place for it in my life.

And if you're determined to feed your kids junk food, how hard is it to go for the stuff without artificial colors? Whole Foods (and other retailers) sell plenty of that, too. After all, if there is a market, the food companies will develop something for it.

Ok, dyes are bad. Blaming hyperactivity on them, however, is like blaming the rolling paper for the toxins that cigarettes deliver to the body. In this case, the tobacco is called SUGAR and there is way too much of it in processed food.
The FDA considers posting warnings for colorings but not for genetically modified or cloned animals?
Wasn't this being said decades ago??  What took so long?

All this artificial junk in our food is killing us. The FDA defines these excitotoxins as safe yet the studies are done by the industry using other compounds as placebox. I no longer trust the government to provide any level of accuracy in information.

Remember, the FDA though saccarine was safe too.
A little radiation here, a little PBA there...and a little blue on the top to make the cake taste umm...so much  better!

While I do agree that food coloring isn't great, but please enough with the special diets. As a child in the 1970's I was subjected to a very strict, Feingold Diet. No artificial colors, flavors, BHT, BHA, MSG or refined sugar or bleached flour. I couldn't even eat regular butter due to the food coloring and my mother made horrible cakes using honey, with carob, wheat flour and so on. After almost a year it was decided there was no change in my 'behavior' and I was allowed to go off the diet. I remember that moment so well and was grateful that i could return to participating in regular children's food activities.

There are children with severe problems who do benefit from special diets, but being healthy, rational and moderate about eating is more important that obsessing about food.

The FDA has never been about deciding what's "right" and "good" -- only about weeding out what will cause lawsuits. What can the FDA be compared to...hmmm... sprinklers that only go off during a fire? The FDA should never be looked to for a source of how to live or care for yourself or your children.

As far as food dyes go... we all know it's junk! Don't pretend you need a warning!
This is way overdue, how about the obvious CANCER links?

I remember reading Kurt Cobain's biography and his mom took the red dye #2 out of his diet.  I think this was a measure to treat his hyperactivity.  I don't know if it worked.  I guess this is an example of parents trying different ways to treat their children before going the route of medicating them.

I just wish there were more options for people who choose to use less of these unnecessary substances for whatever reason. I recently wrote to Kraft about Jell-o -- I was looking for flavors without dyes, and asking about the "sparkling white grape" flavor they used to make. I gave my reasons in my request for why I wanted dye-free products, and I got back a canned reply about how "safe" they were and how "customers expect the color".

The reason I gave them for not wanting the dyes? I give Jell-o (and Pedialyte, and other things) to my son when he's got an upset stomach. When these foods come back up, it's a nasty cleanup job on rugs, towels, sheets, etc, because of the hideous colors. Thankfully Pedialyte comes in dye-free. All I want to do is avoid having to oxy-clean the rugs at 2 am.

I write this because there are many reasons why people want choice -- my son doesn't seem to have any issues with artificial colors when he does have them, but I more than believe that they are triggers for other people. Let's learn to eat food again that looks like food. Maybe I'm just too old, but eating any bright blue food just scares me and holds no appeal.
When will we ever learn?

Hmmmm.  Let's see:  the Lancet, the most respected British medical journal, and a Dutch study and other European studies have all linked artificial ingredients with behavior problems in children.  Are children here different?  No, but our medical research is.  So tied to corporate cash that researchers can barely sneeze without making sure that medical results align with corporate interests, US "research" is often nothing more than a rubber stamp for what industry wants.  I'm not waiting for an agency with a revolving door to industry to tell me whether additives are good or bad.  We just don't eat them in my household.
Kate #37 - ok, but I get the Coco Puffs.

Food dye is often one of the last ingredients listed on commercial food, which means it is used in the least quantity. Can a single drop of it affect human behavior? My kids are not allowed junk food regularly, but from time to time I let them have the sugary, neon, fake treats so that they know what they are and don't covet them so much. My kids are active and at times wild. But they are also extremely bright, imaginative, and advanced for their ages.
More conclusive information on these products would be wonderful, and I stick to the mantra that fresh, healthy and minimally processed foods are the way to go ... but not allowing kids or even adults the indulgence from time to time may drive them to want junk food more in the future. I think a lot of the families who have seen improvements in their kids after cutting the dyes may really just be reaping the benefits of a healthier diet overall.

Three doctors and having two ADD evaluations later, it was recommended that we eliminate artificial dyes from our daughter's diet. It has been seven weeks and the difference in her behavior is astounding.

The accidental reintroduction happens though we read labels like crazy. Last week it was vanilla yogurt from a local shop. I assumed because it was mostly white, and red 40 had been the primary issue, it would be safe. Within two hours, it was all back: her eyes went 'blank', she lost memory of her day, became physically and verbally abusive and ended up curled in a ball shrieking 'somebody help me' alternated with 'don't touch me; I'm so scared'. At a loss, I finally called the yogurt shop; the attendant read the label of the French Vanilla, and, indeed, it contained red 40. We have also accidentally discovered the similarities in other colors as well. Another time in the seven weeks she had a 'meltdown, the only ingredient we could find was in cheddar chex mix -- yellow 5 and 6. Now we know that these yellows are as much of an issue for many as the red.

It is not just the 'fruity' sugar cereals, candy, carbonated beverages. It is in seemingly harmless foods, too. (The rainbow goldfish are labeled as 'now made with natural dyes' -- and who hasn't fed their child goldfish -- the snack that smiles?)

With the elimination of all dyes she has been able to concentrate on school projects for several hours rather than minutes, she wakes up on her own, takes far more responsibility for herself, and is a normative 10-year old in her reactions to the everyday things that kids deal with. She doesn't hit, spit, or grunt, or cry at the drop of a hat, as she did for so many years.

I realize this affects a very small portion of the population, but had I seen a warning on food packages (like listed on children's antihistamines), I think I could have connected the dots. Undoing the damage to my daughter's self-image is our next challenge. For so long she would cry out of her frustration, because she didn't know what was "wrong" with her -- and unfortunately neither did anyone else. One journal article, one caring doctor, thankfully.

Forty years ago, of my four children I often described the third one, a girl, as being "borderline hyperactive." I wasn't making a diagnosis, but she was into everything all day long. From age two she seldom slept more than seven hours at night and never napped. But she was generally a well-behaved child: never loud or aggressive, friendly, eager to please and very bright.

When the family went to spend a year in France my daughter was four, and, true to form, she surprised me with one of her first actions in our rental home – she found scissors and "trimmed" the fringe on the rug in her room. But after a month or so I suddenly realized that she had calmed down. There was no more inventive destruction, no mini-whirlwind, and she slept longer. I was thankful, mystified and wanted to find out why.

I finally decided that the source of the difference in my daughter lay in the food. After all this time I cannot remember the exact numbers, but my recollection is that in France fewer than a dozen food colors were permitted. At the same time the FDA permitted more than 40.

When we returned to the States I carefully monitored my daughter's diet and gradually reintroduced her to prepared foods. We ate very few of these because I loved to cook and my husband and sons, being very athletic, had huge appetites. But we did eat hot dogs about once a week. No more. Red dye.

It was, as another commenter wrote, like a switch. Hot dogs, lunch meats in general, strawberry jam, chocolate in commercial cookies, drinks and cake mixes – and more – were no longer part of my daughter's diet. When it was obvious that these couldn't be avoided, at birthday parties for instance, they were permitted. Then the rest of the family engaged in a kind of relay to keep my daughter physically active and busy so she'd be able to sleep that night.

After a few years, by the age of eight or so, the restrictions were in place only after 4 pm as my daughter seemed to have a lessened susceptibility. But almost 30 years later she told me that she had instituted a similar "curfew" on herself because of her own discovery that there were some foods that kept her awake at night.

This experience certainly made me wonder why on earth the US population has to be pumped full of these chemicals? This story is a single anecdote, but the cause was tested again and again with the same effect. Happily that effect was relatively benign, but it might be much worse for a child with heightened sensitivity. While anecdotal evidence doesn't prove the hypothesis, it can certainly make the case for parental caution and for the need of a well designed, scrupulously conducted scientific study.
Vote with your pocketbook.  Don't Buy It!!

My ADHD son is almost 27.  We were on to this 24 years ago.  We saw a physician who made recommendations based on the link between symptom exacerbation and certain substances in food.  It made a difference.  Think of all the children who could have been helped over the last two and a half decades if it hadn't taken so long for this to become public knowledge. I suspect moneyed interests have a lot to do with the  delay.
I couldn't agree more.

This is a fascinating post with much food for thought. Loss of life depends on deadly places, and economic loss depends on valuation of damaged property. In Japan, the tsunami zone was the top "deadly place" in which a high proportion of fatalities occurred. The built environment outside the tsunami zone sustained massive and costly damage, but caused comparatively little loss of life.

Here in the Pacific Northwest we have two especially "deadly places": the tsunami zone, and our aging public schools plus other unreinforced masonry buildings in historic districts and town centers. The issue here is neither affluence nor poverty, but the fact that our (modern, western) built environment was largely constructed decades before the first evidence showed that great earthquakes could be expected here.We built for one environment, and now find ourselves in quite another.

Oregon's population is about 25% larger than the 3 million in northeast Japan, and not so concentrated on the coast. But our buildings are terribly vulnerable, and on school days more than 561,000 Oregon children are in public school classrooms. The share of our population that spends about 200 days each year in one of our state's deadliest places gives no cause for complacency.
